choices.text: Blunting of the villi in the duodenum and proximal jejunum
Extensive colonic injury with yellow-white adherent layer
Flask-shaped ulcerations in the cecum and ascending colon
Foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with abrupt-onset vomiting followed by frequent, large-volume, watery diarrhea for the last day. She has no prior medical conditions but has not received recommended vaccinations. Physical examination shows mild dehydration. The abdomen is soft and mildly tender to palpation throughout. Bowel sounds are increased. Polymerase chain reaction testing of the stool sample yields a virus with a segmented, double-stranded RNA genome. Which of the following pathologic findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blunting of the villi in the duodenum and proximal jejunum

 

  • Child with abrupt-onset vomiting, profuse watery diarrhea, no vaccinations → classic for rotavirus gastroenteritis.
  • Virology clue: segmented, double-stranded RNA genome = Reoviridae family → Rotavirus.
  • Pathology:
    • Rotavirus infects enterocytes of the duodenum and proximal jejunum.
    • Causes blunting of villi and loss of brush border enzymes → malabsorption and osmotic diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extensive colonic injury with yellow-white adherent layer: Describes pseudomembranous colitis due to Clostridioides difficile, not rotavirus.

 

Option C. Flask-shaped ulcerations in the cecum and ascending colon: Seen in Entamoeba histolytica infection, not viral diarrhea.

 

Option D. Foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria: Pathognomonic for Whipple disease (Tropheryma whipplei), not acute viral gastroenteritis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old nulligravida woman comes to the office with a 2-month history of worsening right pelvic pain. She experiences the pain daily, and its intensity does not vary during her menstrual cycle. In addition, the patient's waist size has increased despite a decreased appetite. Pelvic examination shows an irregularly shaped, fixed adnexal mass. One week later, she undergoes surgery to remove a large ovarian neoplasm. Within the true pelvis, the surgeon can most likely palpate the right ureter immediately anterior to which of the following structures?

choices.text: Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount
Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions
It is not a sexually transmitted infection

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trichomonas vaginalis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

questions.text: What is the function of the muscle marked in the image below, at the metacarpophalangeal joint?

A 24-year-old female presents to your office with burning urination, urgency and frequency. She is sexually active. Urine cultures show catalase-positive, gram-positive cocci. The organism responsible for this patient's symptoms is most likely to be:
A student got his jaw locked while yawning. Identify the muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint?
O Donoghue triad of the knee joint involves which of the following structures:
A technician wants to sterilize the material of the laboratory. Which of the following is a correct combination for him to use?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Liquid paraffin: Hot air oven

 

  • Hot air oven (dry heat sterilization) is used for sterilizing oils, fats, powders, and paraffin.
    • Hot air oven (dry heat sterilization) operates at 160°C for 1 hour (or 170°C for 30 minutes).
  • Mechanism: oxidative damage and protein denaturation.
  • Suitable for materials that are moisture-sensitive or would be damaged by steam.
  • Examples sterilized by hot air oven:
    • Oils and fats (like liquid paraffin)
    • Powders (talc, starch)
    • Glassware (pipettes, Petri dishes, flasks)
    • Metal instruments (scalpels, scissors)

 

  • Therefore, sterilizing liquid paraffin with a hot air oven is correct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heat-sensitive vaccine – Pasteurisation:

 

  • Incorrect.Pasteurisation is used for milk, not vaccines.
  • Heat-sensitive vaccines are sterilized by membrane filtration, not by heat.

 

Option C. LSS medium – Autoclave: Incorrect. Löffler’s serum slope (LSS) medium contains serum which coagulates on heating. It is sterilized by inspiratory (fractional) sterilization/tyndallization, not autoclave.

 

Option D. Catgut sutures – Autoclave: Incorrect. Autoclaving destroys catgut. They are sterilized by radiation like gamma rays.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department unconscious after a motor vehicle accident. NCCT is shown here.  A branch of which of the following arteries is most likely severed in this patient?

A 26-year-old man develops dysuria and purulent urethral discharge following unprotected sex with a new partner. Nucleic acid amplification testing is positive for Neisseria gonorrhea infection. The patient develops antibody against the bacterial pili that enhance attachment to host cells. His symptoms resolve with adequate treatment. His partner does not receive treatment. Several weeks later, the patient develops N gonorrhoeae reinfection after repeat exposure to the same partner. Which of the following is the most likely reason for the lack of long-lasting immunity against the bacteria despite antibody formation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antigenic variation

 

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae frequently causes reinfections because it can change the structure of its surface antigens, particularly the pili and outer membrane proteins.
  • Although the patient forms antibodies against pili after the first infection, new infections occur because the organism undergoes antigenic variation → immune system does not recognize the altered pili.
  • This mechanism explains the lack of long-lasting immunity and why repeat infections are common even with the same partner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antigenic mimicry:

 

  • Occurs when microbial antigens resemble host antigens (eg, Streptococcus pyogenes M protein mimicking cardiac myosin in rheumatic fever).
  • Not the mechanism in gonorrhea reinfection.

 

Option C. Conjugative plasmid: Responsible for antibiotic resistance transfer, not immune evasion.

 

Option D. Low molecular weight antigen: Such antigens may be poorly immunogenic, but gonococcal pili are not low molecular weight antigens; the issue is variation, not weak immunogenicity.

questions.text: Mark the option which develops from the structure marked A?

A 63-year-old male with a history of gastrointestinal bleed has developed a sudden onset shortness of breath. Evaluation shows pulmonary embolism. A filter placement is planned to prevent further embolization. The filter will most likely be placed in which of the following structures?

A lady from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer surrounded by erythema on the right leg. Microscopy of the biopsy from the edge of the ulcer showed organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast. What is the most likely causative agent?

A 23-year-old primigravida woman vaginally delivers a 3600-g girl after a protracted labor. The patient sustains second-degree laceration and repair is planned. Prior to administering local anesthesia, the operator intravaginally palpates bony protrusions located posterolateral to the vaginal sidewalls that are distinct from the rest of the pelvic sidewall. A firm band can also be palpated running medially and posteriorly from the bony prominence to the sacrum. Anesthetic agent is injected around the bony prominence. Which of the following nerves is blocked by the injection?
The culture media shown in the image is an example of:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Selective media for EHEC

questions.text: A 66-year-old man hospitalized 3 days ago for left lower lobe pneumonia is evaluated for persistent fever. He has been receiving the appropriate intravenous antibiotics as determined by antibiotic susceptibility testing of his sputum cultures. The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension. His temperature is 38° C (100.4° F) and pulse is 87/min. Examination shows dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the left lower lung. Imaging studies reveal a loculated, left-sided pleural effusion. A tube is placed to drain the fluid via an incision at the 5th intercostal space in the midaxillary line. Which of the following muscles is most likely to be dissected during the procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serratus anterior

 

During insertion of a chest tube in the 5th intercostal space at the midaxillary line, the layers traversed include skin, subcutaneous tissue, serratus anterior muscle fibers, intercostal muscles, and finally the pleura. Serratus anterior lies along the lateral thoracic wall, covering the ribs in the midaxillary line, making it the key muscle dissected in this approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External oblique: This muscle is part of the anterolateral abdominal wall, not involved in chest tube placement at the 5th intercostal space.

 

Option B. Latissimus dorsi: Though large and located on the posterior thorax, it is more posterior to the midaxillary line. Chest tube placement in the midaxillary region usually avoids this muscle.

 

Option C. Pectoralis major: This muscle lies on the anterior chest wall, covering the upper ribs. At the midaxillary line in the 5th intercostal space, it is not typically encountered.

 

Chest Tube insertion into the Triangle Of Safety:

choices.text: Charcot's artery supplies its posterior limb
Sub lenticular portion contains optic radiation
Largest association fibres in the cerebrum
Injury to the genu will cause I/L facial paralysis

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct about the marked area in the given section?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Charcot's artery supplies its posterior limb.

questions.text: Identify the method of sterilization used below?
The organism whose life cycle is shown below is associated with which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

 

  • The image shows the life cycle of Clonorchis sinensis (Chinese liver fluke).
  • Key features from the diagram:
    • Eggs ingested by snail → cercariae released → encyst as metacercariae in freshwater fish → humans infected by eating undercooked fish.
    • Adult worms live in the biliary ducts of humans.
  • Chronic infection leads to recurrent pyogenic cholangitis, biliary stones, and increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC):

 

  • Associated with chronic Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, and aflatoxin exposure.
  • Not linked with Clonorchis infection.

 

Option C. Gastric carcinoma: Associated with Helicobacter pylori infection, chronic gastritis, nitrosamines, not liver flukes.

 

Option D. Bladder carcinoma: Specifically squamous cell carcinoma of bladder is associated with Schistosoma haematobium infection, not Clonorchis.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old male is evaluated for several months of intermittent dysuria and gross hematuria. The patient notes that he passes blood at the end of urination but has no associated pain. Cystoscopy reveals erythematous areas in the bladder mucosa. Multiple biopsies are taken from the affected sites; histopathological findings are shown in the image below.

Which of the following most likely predisposed this patient to his current condition?

Identify the correct statement:

  1. Type I collagen is seen in bone and elastic cartilage
  2. Reticular fibres are present in lymph nodes, bone marrow and thymus
  3. Right-left movement is by atlanto-axial joint
  4. Costo-transverse joints are plane synovial joints
Which of the given statement is INCORRECT regarding the marked nerve in the given cadaveric image?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Secretomotor to parotid gland

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He had a history of contact with multiple sexual partners. He was diagnosed as HIV positive 6 months back and is poorly adherent to his medications. The fungal culture of sputum was negative. GMS staining is shown here.  What is the most likely causative organism?

A 63-year-old woman has a right-sided ovarian mass found incidentally on transvaginal ultrasound.  Surgery is planned to remove the right ovary, including the mass. To avoid excessive bleeding during the oophorectomy, the surgeon should ligate which of the following structures?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Suspensory ligament of the ovary

questions.text: A 22-year-old male is brought to the hospital due to fever, frontal headache, photophobia, nausea and vomiting. Lumbar puncture was done and CSF analysis shows protein-20mg/dl, glucose-65mg/dl, total leukocyte count-200 with lymphocytic predominance. What is the most likely organism implicated in causing the above condition?

A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department complaining that he has food stuck in his throat. His symptoms started 2 hours ago after eating fish at a local seafood restaurant. He has tried coughing and swallowing multiple times in an attempt to clear the food, but has so far been unsuccessful. The patient denies any difficulty with breathing. He does not appear to be in any distress on physical examination. Laryngoscopy reveals a fish bone lodged in the area marked by blue.  During an attempt to retrieve the fish bone, a nerve is injured deep to the mucosa. Which of the following is most likely to be impaired in this patient?

A 70-year-old man comes to the office due to 3 weeks of unrelenting low back pain. He was grocery shopping when he first noticed the pain. The patient reports no trauma or leg weakness but describes having to strain to urinate. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and has not seen a doctor in the past 5 years. His wife died a year ago, and he now lives alone. The patient is a retired construction worker and has a history of tobacco and marijuana use. There is tenderness in the lower vertebral area. Imaging study of the spine reveals several osteoblastic lesions in the lumbar vertebrae. Which of the following structures was most likely involved during the spread of this patient's disease?

choices.text: Condenser lens-> objective lens- eyepiece lens
Eyepice-> Condensor -> Objective lens

questions.text: A microbiologist intern wanted to study cells and microorganisms. His senior advised him to use a light microscope. What is the correct arrangement from eye to the light source in a light microscope?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Eyepiece lens-> objective lens-> Condenser

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for the varicose vein. He now complains of sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured?

A 23-year-old man comes to the OPD due to penile ulcers that appeared after unprotected sexual intercourse. Physical examination shows 3 subcentimeter ulcers on the penile shaft. Microscopic examination of a scraping from an ulcer base reveals the following. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acyclovir

 

  • The image shows multinucleated giant cells with ground-glass nuclei on Tzanck smear.
  • Clinical findings:
    • Painful penile ulcers appearing after unprotected sex.
    • Multiple, small ulcers with erythematous base.
  • This is classic for Genital herpes, caused by Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) (sometimes HSV-1).
  • Treatment of choice = Acyclovir (or valacyclovir, famciclovir).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Azithromycin:

 

  • Used for Chlamydia trachomatis infections, including nongonococcal urethritis and chancroid (Haemophilus ducreyi).
  • Not effective for HSV.

 

Option C. Fluconazole:

 

  • Used for Candida albicans infections (eg, candidal balanitis or vaginitis).
  • Candida causes erythematous patches with curdy white discharge, not ulcers.

 

Option D. Penicillin:

 

  • Used for Treponema pallidum (syphilis), which causes a painless, indurated chancre, not multiple painful ulcers.

questions.text: A medical resident performs a diagnostic procedure on 32-year-old male. He inserts a needle along the upper border of the 10 rib at the right midaxillary line Which of the following is most likely to be punctured as a result of the intervention?
A chest CT scan is performed on a 35-year-old man who presented with chronic cough and weight loss. Which of the following structures labelled below is a derivative of the common cardinal veins?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

The anatomical structure labeled A in the CT scan is the superior vena cava, which is a direct derivative of the common cardinal veins during embryological development.

 

A: The right common cardinal vein and the right anterior cardinal vein unite to form the superior vena cava, an essential embryological remnant in the adult venous system.

 

B. It is the aorta (ascending/arch), derived from the embryonic truncus arteriosus and aortic arches.

 

C. It is  the pulmonary artery arch, develops from the truncus arteriosus and aortic arches, not from cardinal veins.

 

D. It is Esophagus. The esophagus develops from the anterior foregut during the early weeks of gestation.

 

E. It is Descending Aorta, continuation of Aortic Arch.

questions.text: A sewage worker presented with abdominal pain, jaundice, conjunctival suffusion, and blood in the urine for the past 5 days. Which of the following is the investigation of choice?

choices.text: Immediately lateral to the femoral artery
Immediately medial to the femoral artery
Midway between the iliac crest and the femoral artery
Superior and medial to the pubic tubercle

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman is sent to the hospital from a nursing home after 2 days of fever, confusion, and lethargy. The patient has a history of mild dementia, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. Her temperature is 38.8 C (102 F), blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, and pulse is 1 16/min. She has mild suprapubic and right costovertebral angle tenderness. Her leukocyte count is 18,000/mm, and urinalysis is consistent with acute cystitis. A femoral venous access is planned for administration of intravenous fluids and antibiotics. The femoral artery pulsation is palpable immediately below the inguinal ligament. Which of the following describes the optimal cannulation site for the femoral vein?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Immediately medial to the femoral artery

questions.text: All of the following are true about endotoxin except:

choices.text: External carotid artery, facial artery, ophthalmic artery, retinal artery
External carotid artery, ophthalmic artery, retinal artery
Internal carotid artery, anterior cerebral artery, retinal artery
Internal carotid artery, ophthalmic artery, retinal artery

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to sudden-onset vision loss in his left eye for one hour. He has a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. On examination, the patient can see only hand motions through the left eye. Funduscopic evaluation of the eye shows a cherry-red spot in the macula with surrounding retinal whitening. Cranial nerve examination is otherwise unremarkable. There is a left-sided neck bruit on cardiovascular examination. Which of the following is the most likely path of the embolus causing this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Internal carotid artery, ophthalmic artery, retinal artery

questions.text: 52-year-old postmenopausal woman comes to the office due to leakage of a few urine drops with coughing and sneezing. She has no dysuria, urgency, or changes in urinary frequency. The patient has had 3 spontaneous vaginal deliveries. Physical examination is notable for a mild cystocele. The patient is advised to perform exercises to strengthen her pelvic floor as part of treatment for her symptoms Which of the following structures is the most likely target of the exercise?

choices.text: Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory test is used to diagnose rotavirus diarrhea?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.text: Correct sequence of the muscles forming the floor of the femoral triangle in thigh from medial to lateral is:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Adductor Longus - Pectineus - Psoas - Iliacus

choices.text: Double-stranded DNA → double-stranded DNA template → double-stranded DNA progeny
Double-stranded DNA → RNA template → partially double-stranded DNA progeny
Single-stranded DNA → double-stranded DNA template → single-stranded DNA progeny
Single-stranded RNA → double-stranded DNA template → single-stranded RNA progeny

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man comes to the OPD due to 2 months of fatigue, intermittent arthralgias, and poor appetite. Liver aminotransferases are elevated. Hepatitis serology shows the following:

Hepatitis A virus antibody: negative

Hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb): negative

Hepatitis B core antibody (HBcAb), total: positive

Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg): positive

Hepatitis B E antigen (HBeAg): positive

Hepatitis C virus antibody: negative

Which of the following genome replicative processes is most likely used by the virus infecting this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Double-stranded DNA → RNA template → partially double-stranded DNA progeny

 

  • The patient’s serology:
    • HBsAg positive, HBeAg positive, anti-HBc positive, anti-HBs negative → indicates chronic active Hepatitis B infection.
  • Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a partially double-stranded DNA virus (Hepadnavirus family).
  • Unique replication mechanism:
    1. Viral genome enters nucleus.
    2. Converted to covalently closed circular DNA (cccDNA).
    3. Transcribed by host RNA polymerase II into pregenomic RNA.
    4. Viral reverse transcriptase converts RNA back into DNA.
    5. Produces new virions containing partially double-stranded DNA.

 

This unusual cycle is called reverse transcription DNA virus replication.

questions.text: The given condition is due to persistence of which of the following embryonic vessel?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Persistence of right dorsal aorta

 

The finding described (vascular ring or double aortic arch) is due to the persistence of the right dorsal aorta. This results in a vascular anomaly where the right dorsal aorta fails to regress during development, creating a ring around the trachea and esophagus.

 

  • This anomaly can compress the airway or esophagus, leading to symptoms like chronic cough, dysphagia, or stridor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Persistence of left 4th arch artery: Forms part of the definitive aortic arch (normal development). The left 4th aortic arch gives rise to the arch of aorta between the left common carotid and left subclavian arteries.

 

Option C. Persistence of left dorsal aorta: Forms the descending aorta. Persistence is normal and does not result in vascular anomalies.

 

Option D. Persistence of left 6th arch artery: Gives rise to the ductus arteriosus and pulmonary arteries on the left side. Persistence causes patent ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: Absent cremasteric reflex could be a result of injury to which of the following nerve?
A boy presented with a fever and chills. Rapid test was done and shown below. Which of the following antigens of Plasmodium is used?

A 34-year-old man presented with fever and massive splenomegaly. On palpation, the spleen was 15 cm and directed obliquely when measured from the right iliac fossa. Which of the following structures prevent the vertical and downward descent of the spleen?
Arrange the following in order of being most to least resistant?

choices.text: Ascending palatine branch of facial artery

questions.text: 55-year-old female has been diagnosed with nasopharyngeal carcinoma that has spread to the sinus of Morgagni. Which of the following structures will be affected due to the spread in the sinus of Morgagni?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Ascending palatine branch of facial artery

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are incorrectly matched?

  1. Sternoclavicular joint – Plane synovial joint
  2. Wrist and knuckle joints – Hinge variety of synovial joints
  3. Middle tibiofibular joint – Syndesmosis
  4. Calcaneocuboid joint – Saddle synovial joint
  5. Elbow and ankle joint – Ellipsoid synovial joint

choices.text: Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar
Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies
It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of high fever, multiple seizures, headache, and neck rigidity. CS analysis showed low glucose, high protein, and many polymorphs. The CSF culture showed pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli. What is true about the causative organism?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies

choices.text: 73 degrees Celsius for 20 minutes
63 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes
72 degrees Celsius for 30 seconds

questions.text: Pasteurization is done at?
questions.solution: Ans. B) 63 degree Celsius for 30 minutes

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the OPD due to sore throat and fever. Examination shows mild tonsillar erythema with exudates. A sample from the exudates is obtained. On microscopic evaluation, there are clumped, gram-positive bacteria with polar granules that stain deeply with aniline dyes. Which of the following best explains the pathogenicity of the organism most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Impairment of protein synthesis

questions.text: Fibres from mamillary bodies terminate at which of the following points?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

Fibers from the mammillary bodies (mammillothalamic tract, part of the Papez circuit) terminate at the anterior nucleus of the thalamus.

 

In the illustration, A represents the anterior nucleus of the thalamus, the correct termination point for mammillary body fibers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. B→ Ventro-anterior (VA) nucleus: 

 

  • Function: Motor relay.
  • Connections: Receives input from basal ganglia (globus pallidus) → projects to premotor cortex.

 

Option C. C → Ventro-lateral (VL) nucleus:

 

  • Function: Motor relay.
  • Connections: Receives input from cerebellum & basal ganglia → projects to primary motor cortex.

 

Option D. D → Ventro-posterior lateral (VPL) nucleus:

 

  • Function: Somatosensory relay (body).

 

Connections: Receives medial lemniscus & spinothalamic tract → projects to primary somatosensory cortex.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of the nervous system, which of the following nerves can be tested by touching the highlighted structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IX

 

The highlighted structure in the image is the uvula (part of the soft palate).

 

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) provides sensory innervation (general sensation) to the posterior one-third of the tongue, pharynx, and soft palate (including uvula).
  • During clinical examination, touching the uvula or posterior pharyngeal wall elicits the gag reflex → sensory limb by CN IX, motor limb by CN X.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. X (Vagus nerve):

 

  • Provides motor innervation to most muscles of the pharynx and soft palate (except tensor veli palatini).
  • Responsible for the motor limb of the gag reflex and movement of uvula (deviation test).

 

Option C. XI (Accessory nerve):

 

  • Supplies sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
  • Not involved in gag reflex or sensation of uvula. Tested by Shrugging of Shoulder against resistance. 

 

Option D. XII (Hypoglossal nerve):

 

  • Supplies intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue (except palatoglossus).
  • Tested by tongue protrusion, not by touching uvula.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-1, B-3, C-4, D-2

 

A. BCYE agar → Legionella (1)

 

  • BCYE = Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract agar.
  • Used for isolation of Legionella pneumophila (requires L-cysteine and iron).

 

B. EMJH agar → Leptospira (3)

 

  • EMJH = Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris medium.
  • Specialized medium for culturing Leptospira interrogans.

 

C. PEMBA agar → Bacillus cereus (4)

 

  • PEMBA = Polymyxin Egg Yolk Mannitol Bromothymol Blue Agar.
  • Selective medium for Bacillus cereus (produces bluish colonies with lecithinase activity).

 

D. Butzler’s agar → Campylobacter (2)

 

  • Butzler’s medium is selective for Campylobacter jejuni (contains antibiotics to inhibit competing flora).

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with breast cancer was taken for radical mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection. A few weeks after surgery, she presents with weakness in overhead abduction and winging of the scapula. Which nerve is likely to be injured?

27-year-old man comes to the clinic due to abdominal discomfort and diarrhea. He informed that his symptoms began after he returned from vacation in Thailand two days back. On enquiry it was found that he happened to eat a lot of seafood. Stool sample was collected that revealed pink colored rods on gram stain. On wet mount, fish in stream appearance was seen. The causative agent acts on which of the following receptors?
Identify the organism from the life cycle:

choices.text: Between the internal oblique and external oblique
Between the internal oblique and rectus abdominis
Between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis

questions.text: The neurovascular plane of the abdominal wall lies in?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis

questions.text: A patient presents with gastrointestinal problems including abdominal pain and distension, bloody and mucus-filled diarrhea, and tenesmus, with rectal prolapse. A stool examination is shown. What is the possible causative agent?
A 45-year-old patient presented with difficulty in foot eversion and sensory loss on the lateral leg & dorsum of foot. Which nerve lesion will lead to the following condition:

A 43-year-old, HIV-positive woman comes to the OPD due to lesions on her vulvar and perineal areas for the past 4 weeks. On examination, there are clusters of firm, shiny, round papules that are each 2-6 mm in diameter with central indentation. Microscopic examination of a lesion is shown in the image below:

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presenting condition?
Which of the following is not used for the identification of the facial nerve trunk?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Inferior belly of omohyoid muscle

questions.text: Identify the function of the muscle attached in the given pointed structure of femur bone:
The infection whose life cycle is shown below is transmitted by:
The man present with a case of cervical rib has tingling sensation and paresthesia on the medial side of arm. Which of the following marked structure is most likely affected?

A 5-year-old child presented to emergency department with history of rhinorrhea and a mild non-productive cough and red eyes. He hasn’t received his due vaccinations. On examination white lesions against red background seen on buccal mucosa as shown below. What is the likely cause?
Which artery can be palpated by gently pressing your fingers between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal (Achilles) tendon?
Which structure passes through the marked opening?
Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below:
In a 30-year-old female from a tribal area who presents with fever for the last 3 days, which of the following is the most likely causative agent of her illness based on the peripheral smear?

A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a sore on his right hand. The lesion began as a small, painless papule 3 days ago and rapidly enlarged and ulcerated. He is in the wool business and recently returned from a tour of wool-processing plants in several Asian countries. Physical examination is shown below. The toxin causing edema around this patient's ulcer has a mechanism of action most similar to a different toxin produced by which of the following bacteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bordetella pertussis

 

  • The image and clinical history describe cutaneous anthrax, caused by Bacillus anthracis.
  • Classic lesion: starts as a painless papule → vesicle → ulcer with black eschar and surrounding edema.
  • Occupation: wool/hides exposure → “woolsorter’s disease”.
  • Edema toxin of Bacillus anthracis:
    • Composed of protective antigen + edema factor.
    • Edema factor is an adenylate cyclase → increases intracellular cAMP.
    • This impairs neutrophil function and causes massive edema.
  • A similar toxin mechanism is produced by Bordetella pertussis:
    • Pertussis toxin also increases cAMP, but by ADP-ribosylating Gi protein (inhibits Gi, leading to unopposed adenylate cyclase activity).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium botulinum: 

 

  • Produces a toxin that inhibits acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junction → flaccid paralysis.
  • Mechanism: blocks SNARE proteins, not related to cAMP.

 

Option C. Clostridium difficile: 

 

  • Toxin A (enterotoxin) and Toxin B (cytotoxin) disrupt actin cytoskeleton by inactivating Rho GTPases → cause colonic mucosal injury and pseudomembranous colitis.
  • Not related to adenylate cyclase.

 

Option D. Shigella dysenteriae:

 

  • Produces Shiga toxin → inactivates 60S ribosomal subunit by cleaving rRNA → inhibits protein synthesis and causes cell death.
  • Not related to cAMP.

  1. IVC passes through the central tendon of diaphragm
  2. Left superior intercostal vein drains into the azygos vein

The green line corresponds to which vertebral level?

choices.text: Vaccinating pigs is helpful in disease control

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Japanese encephalitis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Man acts as the reservoir

choices.text: It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia
It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament
It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon
Its fibers fan out with fascia illaca laterally

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the iliopubic tract?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Its fibers fan out with fascia illaca laterally

 

  • The iliopubic tract is a thickened inferior margin of the transversalis fascia.
  • It runs parallel and posterior-inferior to the inguinal ligament (Poupart’s ligament).
  • Laterally, it blends with the fascia iliaca, and medially, it attaches to the pubic bone.
  • It plays an important role in the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and is a landmark in laparoscopic hernia repair.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia: Incorrect. It is a thickening of the transversalis fascia, not lumbar fascia.

 

Option B. It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament: Wrong. It actually lies posterior and inferior to the inguinal ligament (Poupart’s ligament).

 

Option C. It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon: No, it attaches to the iliopubic eminence and pubis, but not in front of the conjoint tendon.

questions.text: In a case of tinea capitis, white powdery colonies were isolated from the hair specimen. The hair perforation test was positive on the isolate. Which of the following is the likely etiology?

A 47-year-old man initially comes to his primary care physician with persistent fever, night sweats, and fatigue. Thorough evaluation yields a diagnosis of chronic myeloid leukemia. While undergoing treatment for his malignancy, the patient comes to the oncologist complaining of headaches, scant nasal discharge, and a problem with his left eye. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the paranasal sinuses in addition to left-sided orbital swelling and cellulitis. Mild proptosis and ptosis of the left eye are also present. Biopsy of his sinus mucosa is shown below. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aspergillus fumigatus

 

  • Patient has CML under treatment → immunocompromised state.
  • Clinical presentation: sinus infection, orbital cellulitis, proptosis, ptosis → invasive fungal sinusitis.
  • Biopsy image shows:
    • Septate hyphae
    • Acute angle (≈45°) branching
      → classic for Aspergillus fumigatus.
  • This is invasive aspergillosis, a life-threatening opportunistic infection in neutropenic or immunosuppressed patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blastomyces dermatitidis:

 

  • Dimorphic fungus.
  • Causes broad-based budding yeast in tissues.
  • Pulmonary disease, skin and bone lesions, not invasive sinusitis with septate hyphae.

 

 

Option C. Mucor (Mucormycosis): 

 

  • Also causes invasive sinusitis in immunocompromised (esp. diabetics in ketoacidosis).
  • But histology shows broad, ribbon-like, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching (90°), not narrow septate hyphae with 45° branching.

 

 

Option D. Coccidioides immitis:

 

  • Causes coccidioidomycosis (Valley fever).
  • Tissue form shows spherules with endospores, not hyphae.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician due to pain, swelling, and erythema affecting his right leg. He says that he suffered a minor cut to his leg a few days ago while cleaning his garage. Physical examination shows an indurated region surrounding a minor laceration that is draining a purulent exudate. He is diagnosed with cellulitis and started on the appropriate treatment. Gram stain of the exudate shows gram-positive cocci in clusters. The organism most likely responsible for this patient's infection synthesizes Protein A as part of its peptidoglycan cell wall that does which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Binds the Fc portion of IgG.

questions.text: Area marked A in the given figure contain all the following, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zonula occludens

 

The area marked A in the image is an intercalated disc of cardiac muscle, which contains

 

Zonula occludens (tight junction) is NOT found in cardiac intercalated discs.

 

Zonula occludens (tight junctions) are specialized connections at the apical surface of epithelial cells that create a seal, preventing passage of substances between adjacent cells. They help maintain cell polarity and tissue compartmentalization. Tight junctions are primarily composed of proteins like claudins and occludin. They are essential for barrier functions in organs such as the intestines and kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

An intercalated disc of cardiac muscle contains:

 

Option B. Zonula adherens (intermediate junction): present in the transverse portion of the disc, provides mechanical linkage.

 

Option C. Macula adherens (desmosome): provides spot adhesions for structural integrity.

 

Option D. Gap junction: facilitates electrical impulse propagation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zonula occludens comprises the tight junctions constituted by members of the transmembrane claudin, occluding, and JAM proteins.
